    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/news/mideast/russian-hand-seen-behind-increased-bombing-syrian-hospitals-n847961?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Six miles can be the difference between life and death for Syria's wounded</title>
      <pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 09:55:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/news/mideast/russian-hand-seen-behind-increased-bombing-syrian-hospitals-n847961?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Ziad Jaber and F. Brinley Bruton  and Elena Holodny and Alice Tidey and Reuters and Associated Press</dc:creator>
      <description>Doctors with the Syrian American Medical Society report a sharp rise in the number of hospital attacks since the start of the year.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2328516/180214-syria-ghouta-airstrike-injured-njs-1002a_5ff35788ff126e623f1f7d4cfaab3ee0.jpg" medium="image" height="1697" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Amer Almohibany</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Syrian rescuers evacuate a person injured following airstrikes<media:description type="plain">Rescuers assist a victim following airstrikes on the besieged rebel-held enclave of Kafr Batna, Syria,  on Feb. 6.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2328521/180214-syria-ghouta-hospital-njs-1010a_21916582a763aef0d5781a6a6d96204f.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Mohammed Badra</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Patients await treatment<media:description type="plain">Patients await treatment at a hospital in Eastern Ghouta, Syria.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/i-hired-stylist-learned-so-much-more-how-dress-ncna848446?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>I hired a stylist and it's the best thing I could have done this year</title>
      <pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 23:18:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/i-hired-stylist-learned-so-much-more-how-dress-ncna848446?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Dana McMahan</dc:creator>
      <description>'I've realized it's okay to invest in clothing that helps me feel like and express myself — my true self.'</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2330446/180215-better-stylist-423p-rs_1c14e857db996eee2d008812fb022f46.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Arman Zhenikeyev</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"><media:description type="plain"></media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/what-happened-when-i-put-myself-first-every-situation-ncna815746?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>I stopped saying 'yes' to everyone, and it changed my life</title>
      <pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 19:34:06 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/what-happened-when-i-put-myself-first-every-situation-ncna815746?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Laura Delarato</dc:creator>
      <description>I took a 30-day challenge to say "yes" to myself.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2017_44/2207871/171030-morning-by-the-lake-ac-604p_2b452a154314938a872fbd194b9319df.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Borut Trdina</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Morning By The Lake<media:description type="plain">After a month of worrying only about herself, Delarato was surprised to find all of her relationships stronger.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-care/sneeze-machine-study-takes-deep-dive-how-flu-spreads-n847636?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>How does flu spread? Hitting the dorms to find out</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 21:18:25 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-care/sneeze-machine-study-takes-deep-dive-how-flu-spreads-n847636?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>If you want to know how flu spreads, there's no better place to study than a college dorm</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2327266/1802013_flu-lab-al-1233_512a8cc576732cd18c87f9f49731d3e2.jpg" medium="image" height="1609" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Maggie Fox</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Flu lab at the University of Maryland<media:description type="plain">Dr. Sanmi Adenaiye, a graduate student at the Univerrsity of Maryland, takes blood from Namitha Thomas, a fellow student who has been in close contact with a flu patient. They are studying how influenza spreads.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2327306/image6_052ceb8f101a06268a9bdda7c17ec3b5.jpeg" medium="image" height="1512" width="2016">
        <media:credit>Maggie Fox</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"><media:description type="plain">Hannah Weisman, a neurobiology major at the University of Maryland, helps fellow student Namitha Thomas clip her fingernails as part of a study of how flu spreads.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2327271/1802013_flu-lab-al-1234_512a8cc576732cd18c87f9f49731d3e2.jpg" medium="image" height="1868" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Maggie Fox</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Gesundheit 2 machine<media:description type="plain">Stefanos Koutsoukos, a University of Maryland student, demonstrates the Gesundheit 2 machine that gathers viruses from exhaled breath for experiments on how flu spreads.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/here-s-why-it-s-so-hard-make-better-flu-n848081?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Why it's so hard to make a better flu vaccine</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 18:26:23 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/here-s-why-it-s-so-hard-make-better-flu-n848081?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Making a universal flu vaccine is turning out to be harder than anyone thought. Why? Because influenza virus is a master of cloaking technology.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_04/2307081/180126-influenza-syringe-ac-601p_e2d169c45b9e33c3d8f0e61143daf66e.jpg" medium="image" height="1666" width="2500">
        <media:credit>John Brecher</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: H1N1 vaccine<media:description type="plain">A syringe contnaining H1N1 vaccine.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2327746/180213-influenza-ferritin-a-harris-ew-636p_f843572f6467d179388dfead274d67da.jpg" medium="image" height="722" width="722">
        <media:credit>John Gallagher and Audray Harris</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: A prototype for a universal flu vaccine<media:description type="plain">A prototype for a universal flu vaccine. The nanoparticle is a hybrid of a protein scaffold (blue) and eight influenza hemagglutinin proteins on the surface (yellow). The hemagglutinin was specifically engineered to display antibody binding sites common to all human influenza subtypes.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_04/2304171/180124-flu-vaccine-lab-ew-101p_a9e8490e2d0cc350ec8da8ef7fb31d0f.jpg" medium="image" height="1770" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Carolyn Kaster</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Jason Plyler<media:description type="plain">Biologist Jason Plyler prepares to test how immune cells react to possible flu vaccines at the Vaccine Research Center at the National Institutes of Health on Dec. 19, 2017, in Bethesda, Maryland.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/flu-vaccine-works-better-feared-it-s-still-not-great-n848351?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Flu vaccine works better than expected</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 18:24:09 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/flu-vaccine-works-better-feared-it-s-still-not-great-n848351?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Children ages 8 and under are well protected against the most common strain, CDC finds</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2323196/180209-flu-1225p-rs_19654ea31217e90bfeadb93bdea246a5.JPG" medium="image" height="1757" width="2500">
        <media:credit>David Goldman</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Reed Olson, 8, gets a flu shot at a Dekalb County health center in Decatur, Georgia, on Feb. 5, 2018.<media:description type="plain">Reed Olson, 8, gets a flu shot at a Dekalb County health center in Decatur, Georgia, on Feb. 5, 2018. </media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/your-brain-prayer-meditation-ncna812376?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>What happens to our brains when we pray?</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 18:02:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/your-brain-prayer-meditation-ncna812376?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Nicole Spector</dc:creator>
      <description>How does the ritual, regardless of personal faith or intention, affect our behavior? Deeply, experts say.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2017_42/2195336/171019-prayer-hands-mn-1540_20de83fb1d4fe134769a4c394e86632a.jpg" medium="image" height="1365" width="2048">
        <media:credit>Getty Images/EyeEm</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Prayer<media:description type="plain">There is research backing the idea that meditation and prayer can trigger the release of feel-good chemicals in the brain.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/highly-processed-foods-may-raise-cancer-risk-study-finds-n848186?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Processed foods like bread may raise cancer risk</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 12:17:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/highly-processed-foods-may-raise-cancer-risk-study-finds-n848186?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Cheese, pasta, canned foods did not raise risk</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2014_27/541386/140701-belgium-fries-revolution-1042a_c0544384cb1338e2a02d845f7396199e.jpg" medium="image" height="1849" width="2500">
        <media:credit>GEORGES GOBET</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: A woman eats French fries (fried chips) with mayonnaise on the "Chips Revolution" Day" in Leuven<media:description type="plain">A woman eats French fries with mayonnaise  in Belgium </media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/cuban-embassy-staff-had-concussion-injuries-doctors-say-n848291?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Cuba embassy staff had concussion-like injury</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 12:15:14 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/cuban-embassy-staff-had-concussion-injuries-doctors-say-n848291?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Medical exams raise more questions than answers</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2268626/171212-us-embassy-cuba_935e0f137a65f05a81fa8b257043a19c.jpg" medium="image" height="2334" width="3500">
        <media:credit>ALEXANDRE MENEGHINI</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: People talk to security officials at the U.S. Embassy in Havana<media:description type="plain">People talk to security officials at the U.S. Embassy in Havana, Cuba, December 12, 2017.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/5-scientifically-proven-ways-reduce-muscle-soreness-ncna848001?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>5 science-backed ways to reduce muscle soreness</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 20:56:14 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/5-scientifically-proven-ways-reduce-muscle-soreness-ncna848001?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>K. Aleisha Fetters / Life by Daily Burn</dc:creator>
      <description>What you can do today to be back in the gym tomorrow.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2328741/reduce_muscle_soreness_better_708eb3e9c33f7a9b23c975c52b004ec6.jpg" medium="image" height="3648" width="5472">
        <media:credit>Twenty20</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"><media:description type="plain">Delayed onset muscle soreness, also known as DOMS, describes the muscular pain and stiffness that set in after a particularly intense workout.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/flu-shot-fail-why-doesn-t-vaccine-always-work-n21446?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Why doesn't the flu vaccine always work?</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 17:05:57 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/flu-shot-fail-why-doesn-t-vaccine-always-work-n21446?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Flu shots don't work as well as other vaccines, and doctors and patients alike struggle to understand why.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2014_06/159451/140203-flu-shot-02_7390747aba17f213fa0948321c47235b.jpg" medium="image" height="1646" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Justin Sullivan</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"><media:description type="plain">Doctors are still flummoxed by how difficult it is to make a good vaccine against influenza.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2014_09/107051/new-140109-flu-shots-2211_624c469e46edd9443988a42c6a44b66a.jpg" medium="image" height="3087" width="4630">
        <media:credit>Matt Rourke</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Vials of flu vaccine<media:description type="plain">In any given year, a flu shot is only about 60 percent effective.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2014_06/159446/140124-flu-outbreak-03_b24420a86205bd6341725c95d6141f63.jpg" medium="image" height="1718" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Justin Sullivan</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Flu Outbreak Continues In Bay Area<media:description type="plain">Public health officials say flu shots are still the best protection we have.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/fda-approves-new-blood-test-detect-concussions-n848131?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Blood test finds concussions without CT scan</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 15 Feb 2018 12:24:25 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/fda-approves-new-blood-test-detect-concussions-n848131?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>FDA says approval can save money and effort</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/1475696/160328-doctor-linda-papa-concussion-blood-tests-mdl_ce20e141d47842de0ade761ebfa9fb38.jpg" medium="image" height="3353" width="4220">
        <media:credit>Orlando Health via AP</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Linda Papa<media:description type="plain">Dr. Linda Papa,  an emergency medicine physician at Orlando Health in Orlando, Fla. holds a blood sample used for a newly approved blood test for concussion. </media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/how-mental-health-experts-talk-their-kids-about-school-shootings-ncna845586?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>What mental health experts say to their kids about school shootings</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 14 Feb 2018 22:18:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/how-mental-health-experts-talk-their-kids-about-school-shootings-ncna845586?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Nicole Spector</dc:creator>
      <description>How to help your kids feel safe when their world feels out of control.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2314201/180201-la-shooting-ac-759p_bbc04adc157951e251d38874f1e2af08.jpg" medium="image" height="1922" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Damian Dovarganes</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: LA Shooting Aftermath<media:description type="plain">Perhaps the most troubling issue for parents is that part of their job is to help their children feel safe in a world that can turn deadly in an instant.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/why-falling-love-gives-you-butterflies-ncna847951?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Why falling in love gives you butterflies</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 14 Feb 2018 16:28:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/why-falling-love-gives-you-butterflies-ncna847951?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Nicole Spector</dc:creator>
      <description>These swoony sensations we recognize as signs of true love are really more about lust.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/909221/150227-scince-monarch-butterfly_a011bb8313e597035485fe55244ff0b2.jpg" medium="image" height="2082" width="3144">
        <media:credit>Michael Fiala</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Monarch butterfly<media:description type="plain">When you get nervous or excited, a nerve is stimulated that activates the gut and causes that fluttering feeling in your stomach. </media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/how-often-do-happiest-couples-have-sex-it-s-less-ncna828491?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>How often do happy couples have sex? Less than you think.</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 14 Feb 2018 15:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/how-often-do-happiest-couples-have-sex-it-s-less-ncna828491?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Wendy Rose Gould</dc:creator>
      <description>Once a week is "just right" for sexual happiness, according to a study.  But there's no magic formula.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/1821406/161205-best-sex-mbe-620p_7126d3e6126b1459b7673c671b90fb66.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Tom Merton</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Richard & Kirstin bed feet -009<media:description type="plain">A 2017 study that appeared in the Archives of Sexual Behavior found that the average adult currently enjoys sex 54 times a year, which equates to about once a week. </media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/14-gifts-will-strengthen-your-relationship-ncna830771?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Last-minute Valentine's Day gifts that will strengthen your relationship</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 14 Feb 2018 14:45:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/14-gifts-will-strengthen-your-relationship-ncna830771?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Nadine Jolie Courtney</dc:creator>
      <description>Skip the box of chocolate. This year, give a gift you can enjoy together.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2327136/180213-valentines-gift-stock-al-1059_23e591b1cb37cfdfcc2533787b567d4f.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>VisitBritain</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Valentine's gift<media:description type="plain">Replace the heart-shaped candy box with a present that will bring the two of you together. </media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2017_51/2265821/truly_madly_deeply_6b9a7987afd07cc31159ea28d26b7f8c.jpg" medium="image" height="1496" width="1500">
        <media:credit>Studio Oh!</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"><media:description type="plain"></media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2017_51/2265806/serenflipity2_6d9a2e851f5dba4fa50ff5bd637232f9.jpg" medium="image" height="3840" width="3840">
        <media:credit>Serenflipity</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"><media:description type="plain"></media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2017_51/2267131/knack_date_night_mn_2fc0b8de8e1519085110d8a37a4c66fb.jpg" medium="image" height="1160" width="1850">

    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/why-marriage-therapist-says-good-enough-relationship-one-lasts-lifetime-ncna847611?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Why a 'good enough' relationship is one that lasts a lifetime</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 14 Feb 2018 14:44:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/why-marriage-therapist-says-good-enough-relationship-one-lasts-lifetime-ncna847611?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Julie Compton</dc:creator>
      <description>Couples in a "good enough" relationship settle for nothing less than being treated with honesty, respect and affection, says relationship therapist John Gottman.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2017_26/2054001/170626-better-old-couple-holding-hands-se-558p_f0f55b9fd9bf594129c9267c103cf8ef.jpg" medium="image" height="1505" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Kathleen Finlay</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: An elderly couple holds hands on a park bench<media:description type="plain">With trust and commitment come friendship and intimacy, essential ingredients for a relationship that lasts a lifetime.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/women-twice-likely-men-have-depression-survey-finds-n847556?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Women twice as likely as men to be depressed</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 14 Feb 2018 13:00:57 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/women-twice-likely-men-have-depression-survey-finds-n847556?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Blacks have highest rates of depression</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2017_03/1866241/170116-depression-cr-0656-cr_01_ebb5bf91d769c4dcd99096a6791a1e44.jpg" medium="image" height="1475" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Christopher Furlong</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Winter Blues Beckon As Daylight Hours Foreshorten<media:description type="plain">About 8 percent of Americans report symptoms of depression in any given two week period, the CDC says.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>

    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/pop-culture/movies/sony-apologizes-peter-rabbit-movie-makes-parents-hopping-mad-n847206?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Sony apologizes as 'Peter Rabbit' movie makes parents hopping mad</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 12 Feb 2018 22:29:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/pop-culture/movies/sony-apologizes-peter-rabbit-movie-makes-parents-hopping-mad-n847206?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Kiara Alfonseca</dc:creator>
      <description>Sony Pictures and "Peter Rabbit" filmmakers apologized for a controversial "food allergy bullying" scene that prompted backlash from allergy awareness organizations.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_07/2325626/180212-peter-rabbit-se-1148a_662d2283cb6053db009af04657006475.jpg" medium="image" height="1135" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Sony Pictures</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Flopsy, Mopsy, Benjamin and Cottontail in the movie "Peter Rabbit"<media:description type="plain">Flopsy, from left, Mopsy, Benjamin and Cottontail in the movie "Peter Rabbit."</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/ultrasounds-unlikely-cause-autism-study-finds-n847246?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Can ultrasounds cause autism?</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 12 Feb 2018 19:59:24 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/ultrasounds-unlikely-cause-autism-study-finds-n847246?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Ultrasounds during pregnancy do not appear to be a major cause of autism, researchers found. But they said pregnant women need to limit how many they have.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_28/1619951/1607-zika-jhc-1120_bd6076257a27a8622257973c54d68cf8.JPG" medium="image" height="3063" width="4594">
        <media:credit>Jennifer Weiss</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Zika<media:description type="plain">Victoria Eljach, 22 weeks pregnant, watches as Dr. Juan Franco performs an ultrasound on her Friday, July 8, 2016, in Houston. A new study appears to help clear medical ultrasounds of causing autism.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/new-ultrasound-treatment-stops-essential-tremors-n846096?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>'Burning a hole in the brain' can fix it</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 12 Feb 2018 13:00:02 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/new-ultrasound-treatment-stops-essential-tremors-n846096?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Follow the remarkable improvement of one man with palsy after undergoing noninvasive procedure</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2322056/180208-tremors-ac-543p_793a9626418fe3e480443f158666f28d.jpg" medium="image" height="1875" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Maggie Fox</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Patient Treatment<media:description type="plain">MRI technicians Leonard Valentine and Andy Hebel at the at the University of Maryland Medical Center check on patient Tim Dobbyn as he undergoes focused ultrasound treatment for essential tremor on Jan. 18, 2018</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2322061/180208-tremors-ac-542p_3b0ada94e4aa7b8a3a7981466f1354bc.jpg" medium="image" height="1875" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Maggie Fox</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Patient Treatment<media:description type="plain">Dr. Howard Eisenberg, professor of neurosurgery at the University of Maryland Medical Center, checks MRI scans of patient Tim Dobbyn's brain as he undergoes focused ultrasound treatment for essential tremor on Jan. 18, 2018</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2322056/180208-tremors-ac-543p_793a9626418fe3e480443f158666f28d.jpg" medium="image" height="1875" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Maggie Fox</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Patient Treatment<media:description type="plain">MRI technicians Leonard Valentine and Andy Hebel at the at the University of Maryland Medical Center check on patient Tim Dobbyn as he undergoes focused ultrasound treatment for essential tremor on Jan. 18, 2018</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2322051/180208-tremors-ac-540p_252f669ce9b620262f1c8f727764db0b.jpg" medium="image" height="1613" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Maggie Fox</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Patient Treatment<media:description type="plain">MRI technicians Leonard Valentine and Andy Hebel at the at the University of Maryland Medical Center check on patient Tim Dobbyn as he undergoes focused ultrasound treatment for essential tremor on Jan. 18, 2018</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2322046/180208-tremors-ac-541p_2760792d9bd7e9af793ba079f98433c0.jpg" medium="image" height="1866" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Maggie Fox</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Patient Treatment<media:description type="plain">Tim Dobbyn drinks a bottle of water using his left hand only after undergoing focused ultrasound treatment for his essential tremor at the University of Maryland Medical Center</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/flu-season-breaking-records-cdc-says-n846341?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>Flu season is breaking records, CDC says</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 12 Feb 2018 12:58:52 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/flu-season-breaking-records-cdc-says-n846341?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Flu season is getting worse and is on course to break records in terms of people made sick by influenza and sent to the hospital with flu, the CDC says.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2323201/180209-flu-2-1226p-rs_19654ea31217e90bfeadb93bdea246a5.JPG" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Robert Ray</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Dr. Doug Olson asks patient William Ness, 70, how he is feeling after his wife drove him to the emergency room and he was diagnosed with flu at Northside Hospital Emergency Room in Cumming, Georgia, on Jan. 29, 2018.<media:description type="plain">Dr. Doug Olson asks patient William Ness, 70, how he is feeling after his wife drove him to the emergency room and he was diagnosed with flu at Northside Hospital Emergency Room in Cumming, Georgia, on Jan. 29, 2018. Olson says the hospital has been flooded with flu patients, prompting hospital crowding and shift changes to accommodate the traffic.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2323256/n180209-flu_bae0cfe6fce7eaa1ad94c6fe28c395c0.jpg" medium="image" height="1236" width="1200">
        <media:credit></media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Influenza-related hospitalizations as of Feb. 3, 2018<media:description type="plain"></media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/health/cancer/genetic-similarities-between-dogs-people-are-helping-cancer-research-n841556?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>How dogs are helping treat cancer in people</title>
      <pubDate>Sun, 11 Feb 2018 00:58:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/health/cancer/genetic-similarities-between-dogs-people-are-helping-cancer-research-n841556?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Shamard Charles, MD and Lauren Dunn</dc:creator>
      <description>Genetic similarities between canines and humans may provide clues to treat disease more effectively</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2324156/180210-torres-dog-oncology-1-ew-335p_d7dc8261e44cf823b5449f5ffcdbfb04.jpg" medium="image" height="1080" width="1920">
        <media:credit>NBC News</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Emily Brown, 31, and her dog.<media:description type="plain">Emily Brown, 31, and her golden retriever who was recently diagnosed with soft tissue sarcoma and is going through her own treatment.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/americas-heroin-epidemic/oxycontin-maker-purdue-stop-promoting-opioids-light-epidemic-n846726?cid=public-rss_20180218</guid>
      <title>OxyContin maker to stop promotions amid epidemic</title>
      <pubDate>Sun, 11 Feb 2018 00:53:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>https://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/americas-heroin-epidemic/oxycontin-maker-purdue-stop-promoting-opioids-light-epidemic-n846726?cid=public-rss_20180218</link>
      <dc:creator>Phil McCausland and Tracy Connor</dc:creator>
      <description>Purdue Pharma announced on Saturday that they would stop marketing opioid drugs to doctors.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2324336/180210-purdue-pharma-503p-rs_bfa64beddeb0d9d31772a3c7afdf4f6d.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Kristoffer Tripplaar</media:credit>

      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2018_06/2324336/180210-purdue-pharma-503p-rs_bfa64beddeb0d9d31772a3c7afdf4f6d.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Kristoffer Tripplaar</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">NC: A logo sign outside of a facility occupied by Purdue Pharma L.P., in Wilson, North Carolina on Nov. 27, 2015.<media:description type="plain">A logo sign outside of a facility occupied by Purdue Pharma L.P., in Wilson, North Carolina on Nov. 27, 2015.</media:description></media:text>
      </media:content>
    </item>
